questions.text: Match the following declarations with their agendas?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Declaration of Tokyo: This was adopted in 1975 (amended in 2005 and 2006) during the assembly of the WMA. It refers to the guidelines for doctors concerning torture, degradation or cruel treatment of prisoners. Declaration of Helsinki: The WMA originally developed this declaration in 1964 and underwent major revision in 1975. It refers to the ethical principles for medical research involving human subjects, including research on identifiable human material and data. Declaration of Oslo: It was a statement by the WMA in 1970 on therapeutic abortion and amended in 1983 and 2006. Declaration of Ottawa: This declaration on child health was adopted by the WMA in 1998 (amended in 2009). Physicians along with parents, and with world leaders to advocate for healthy children.

questions.text: The name of the doctor is permanently removed from the SMC Register.This will be referred to which of the following terms given below?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The name of the doctor is removed from the SMC register: • After the death of a registered medical practitioner. • When entries of the medical practitioner are erroneous or fraudulent. • In case of professional misconduct which is known as penal erasure. When the name is permanently removed, it is termed as a professional death sentence. • Such erasure is known as penal erasure & when it is permanent, it is known as professional death sentence. It deprives the practitioner of all the privileges of a RMP. • A medical practitioner is entitled to appeal to the Federal Health Ministry against the decision of PMDC. • When the registered medical practitioner is not traceable at the address recorded with the council. Professional(Infamous conduct)-Any conduct of the doctor which might reasonably be regarded as disgraceful or dishonorable as judged by professional men of good repute and competence. It involves abuse of professional position. Medical negligence—where the standard of medical care given to a patient is considered to be inadequate.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the emergency department in an unconscious state with an imminent danger to the life of the patient and the designated surrogate is unavailable,then the law presumes that consent has been deemed to be given.This type of consent is known as?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Implied Consent. Implied Consent is correct because, in emergency medical situations where the patient is unconscious and unable to provide explicit consent, the law presumes that consent has been given. This is called implied consent, meaning that consent is inferred from the circumstances, such as the need to provide urgent medical care to save the person's life. In this case, the law assumes that if the patient were conscious, they would consent to the necessary life-saving interventions. Implied consent is commonly applied in situations like accidents, unconsciousness, or when the designated surrogate is unavailable. Incorrect Options: A. Blanket Consent This is incorrect because blanket consent refers to a broad, generalized form of consent given for all future medical treatments or procedures. It is not specific to an emergency situation and does not apply to cases where consent is presumed due to unconsciousness or imminent danger. Blanket consent is more applicable to situations where ongoing consent is provided for medical treatment without needing to give consent for each individual procedure. C. Expressed Consent This is incorrect because expressed consent is explicit consent given by the patient, either verbally or in writing, for a specific medical treatment or procedure. In the case described in the question, the patient is unconscious and cannot express their consent, which is why implied consent is presumed by the law instead of expressed consent. D. Informed Consent This is incorrect because informed consent requires the patient to be informed about the nature of the medical treatment, the risks, and benefits, and to voluntarily agree to the treatment. In the situation described in the question, the patient is unconscious and cannot be informed or provide voluntary consent, so informed consent is not applicable. Implied consent, based on the emergency nature of the situation, is the appropriate legal presumption.

questions.text: Whoever causes the death of any person by doing any rash or negligent act not amounting to culpable homicide is punished with imprisonment upto 2 years and with/without fine’. This law comes under which section of the Indian Penal Code?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Sec. 304-A IPC deals with criminal negligence; `whoever causes the death of any person by doing any rash or negligent act not amounting to culpable homicide is punished with imprisonment upto 2 years and with/without fine’. The police sometimes register the cases of professional negligence deaths under Sec. 304 IPC which is a non-bailable offence, whereas if it is registered under Sec. 304-A IPC, the offence is bailable. The basic difference is that in Sec. 304, the act is intentional, while in 304-A, the act is never done with the intention to cause death. Sec 299 IPC- Culpable homicide.—Whoever causes death by doing an act with the intention of causing death, or with the intention of causing such bodily injury as is likely to cause death, or with the knowledge that he is likely by such act to cause death, commits the offence of culpable homicide Sec 300 IPC- Murder.—Except in the cases hereinafter excepted, culpable homicide is murder, if the act by which the death is caused is done with the intention of causing death, or— (Secondly) —If it is done with the intention of causing such bodily injury as the offender knows to be likely to cause the death of the person to whom the harm is caused, or— (Thirdly) —If it is done with the intention of causing bodily injury to any person and the bodily injury intended to be in­flicted is sufficient in the ordinary course of nature to cause death, or— (Fourthly) —If the person committing the act knows that it is so imminently dangerous that it must, in all probability, cause death or such bodily injury as is likely to cause death, and commits such act without any excuse for incurring the risk of causing death or such injury as aforesaid.

questions.text: In civil negligence cases against the doctor, the burden of the proof lies with which of the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) In civil negligence cases, such as those involving medical malpractice or negligence, the burden of proof lies with the plaintiff—in this case, the patient. The patient must prove that the doctor was negligent in their duty of care, which resulted in harm or injury. The patient is required to provide sufficient evidence to demonstrate that the standard of care was breached and that this breach directly caused the injury or damage. The doctor is not required to prove their innocence, but instead, they may provide a defense to challenge the claims made by the patient. This is typical in civil cases, where the burden of proof rests with the person making the claim (the patient), rather than the accused party (the doctor). Incorrect Options: A. Doctor: In civil negligence cases, it is not the doctor's responsibility to prove their innocence but rather to defend against the claim made by the patient. The burden of proof lies with the plaintiff (the patient). C. First class judicial magistrate: A First Class Judicial Magistrate is a judicial officer who oversees legal proceedings and does not bear the burden of proof in civil negligence cases. Their role is to ensure a fair trial, not to provide evidence or prove claims. D. Police not below the rank of sub-inspector: The police may assist in investigating the case, but they are not responsible for the burden of proof in civil negligence cases. The burden lies with the patient, who must present evidence to support their claim.

questions.text: A doctor performed surgery on a patient but failed to remove swabs from the incision leaving it inside the abdomen causing further complications and harm to the patient.This will come under which of the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The patient need not prove negligence in a case where the rule of res ipsa loquitur applies, which means ‘the thing or fact speaks for itself.’ • Applies to both civil and criminal negligence. • Error is so self-evident that the patient’s lawyer need not prove the doctor’s guilt with medical evidence. The doctor has to prove his innocence.Rule is applied when the following three conditions are satisfied: i. In the absence of negligence, the injury would not have occurred, i.e. its occurrence ordinarily be speaks negligence. ii. Doctors had exclusive control over the injury producing instrument/treatment. iii. Patient was not guilty of contributory negligence, injury was not the result of his own voluntary act or neglect. Doctrine of Res Ipsa Loquitur Examples- • Failure to remove swabs/cottons during operation which may lead to complications or cause death • Prescribing an overdose of medications which may cause death • Blood transfusion misadventure

questions.text: A physician performs an unauthorized operation on a patient.He may be punished for?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Civil and Criminal Negligence both. Civil and Criminal Negligence both is correct because performing an unauthorized operation on a patient is both a violation of legal duty and a breach of medical ethics. This act can be considered civil negligence because it involves the patient's right to autonomy and consent, leading to potential civil lawsuits for compensation for damages, including pain and suffering, or medical costs. It is also criminal negligence because performing an unauthorized operation constitutes a breach of the law, and the physician can be held criminally responsible for harm caused due to the lack of consent. In this case, the physician could face charges for performing an unauthorized procedure, which could lead to criminal penalties, in addition to civil liabilities for damages. Incorrect Options: A. Civil Negligence This is incorrect because civil negligence refers to a failure to meet a standard of care that causes harm or damage to a person, typically leading to civil liability for compensation. While an unauthorized operation could involve civil negligence, this option does not fully encompass the severity of the physician's action. The physician's act is not only a civil violation but also a criminal offense because it involves performing an operation without consent, which can lead to both civil and criminal consequences. B. Criminal Negligence This is incorrect because while criminal negligence could apply to situations where a physician's actions cause harm due to failure to exercise due care, performing an unauthorized operation goes beyond mere negligence. It is a deliberate violation of the patient's rights and is treated as both a criminal act and civil violation. Hence, both civil and criminal negligence apply in this scenario, rather than just criminal negligence alone. D. Contributory Negligence This is incorrect because contributory negligence refers to a situation where the injured party (in this case, the patient) contributes to their own injury through their own negligence. In the scenario described, the physician is solely responsible for the unauthorized operation, and the patient’s role in the incident does not involve contributory negligence. The physician’s actions are the direct cause of the harm, making contributory negligence irrelevant.

questions.text: A consent is considered invalid if ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Consent is invalid if: • It is not an informed consent. • Given for committing a crime or an illegal act, such as criminal abortion. • Obtained by misrepresentation or fraud. • Given by one who had no legal capacity to give it, e.g. a minor or an insane person. Substituted consent: If a person in need of treatment is incapable of giving informed consent, consent (proxy consent) must be obtained from next of kin. The order of succession is generally spouse, adult child, parent and sibling. Blanket (open) consent: The consent taken at the time of admission, and practiced in most hospitals that cover almost everything a doctor might do to a patient without mentioning anything specific. It is of questionable legal validity. Presumed consent assumes that an individual agrees in principle to the said procedure; if not, he/she must withdraw his/her consent, i.e. ‘opt out.

questions.text: Hospital management is held responsible for the mistakes of resident physicians and interns in training, who are considered employees when performing their normal duties. This statement will be applicable to which of the following below?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) An employer is responsible not only for his own negligent act, but also for the negligent act of his employees by the principle of ‘respondeat superior’ (Latin, ‘let the master answer’), if three conditions are satisfied: i. There must be an employer-employee relationship ii. The employee’s conduct must occur within the scope of his employment iii. Incidents must occur while on the job. Hospital management cannot be held responsible for the negligent acts of members of the senior medical staff in the treatment of patients, if it can be proved that the management exercised due care and skill, in selecting properly qualified and experienced staff. Hospital management is held responsible for the mistakes of resident physicians and interns in training, who are considered employees when performing their normal duties. A physician is responsible for the acts of the interns and residents carried out under his direct supervision and control.

questions.text: Which of the following does not come under Therapeutic misadventure ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Therapeutic misadventure refers to an unintended injury or harm that occurs during medical treatment, even though the treatment was correctly administered. In other words, it's an adverse event that occurs despite following proper procedures and protocols. A. Medication errors Does not come under therapeutic misadventure because medication errors involve preventable mistakes, such as giving the wrong drug, dosage, or route. These are not misadventures because they are due to errors or negligence. B. Medical and surgical complications These can be considered therapeutic misadventures if they occur despite proper procedures. For example, bleeding or infection post-surgery, even when the surgery was conducted correctly. C. Iatrogenic and nosocomial infections Iatrogenic infections (caused by medical treatment) and nosocomial infections (hospital-acquired) can fall under therapeutic misadventures because they may arise even with proper medical procedures. D. Hypersensitivity reactions to penicillin These are unintended adverse reactions that can occur despite correct prescription and administration of penicillin. Hypersensitivity reactions are a classic example of a therapeutic misadventure, as they are not preventable in all cases.

Error is so self-evident that the patient’s lawyer need not prove the doctor’s guilt with medical evidence. The doctor has to prove his innocence. Rule is applied when the following three conditions are satisfied: i. In the absence of negligence, the injury would not have occurred, i.e. its occurrence ordinarily bespeaks negligence. ii. Doctor had exclusive control over the injury producing instrument/treatment. iii. questions.text: A child under 12 years of age and an insane person cannot give valid consent to suffer any harm which may result from an act done in good faith and for their benefit. In such cases, the consent of the parent or guardian should be obtained. This provision is covered under which section of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS), 2023?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Section 30 of the BNS corresponds to Section 89 of IPC, which deals with acts done in good faith for the benefit of a person who is a child (under 12 years) or of unsound mind, with the consent of a guardian or person in lawful charge. This section states that consent from the individual themselves is not valid, but the act will not be an offence if done in good faith and with guardian consent.

questions.text: The doctor is liable to be sued by the patient until what time after the occurrence of medical negligence?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) In case of alleged negligence, following may be helpful for defense: • No duty owed to the patient, i.e. no doctor-patient relationship was established. • Duty discharged according to prevailing standards. • Informed consent for the act: The patient was duly informed of the consequences. • Patient was guilty of contributory negligence. • Therapeutic misadventure. • Medical maloccurrence. The case against the doctor should be filed within 2 years from the date of alleged negligence.No fee was charged for the treatment cannot be a defense in cases of negligence.

questions.text: A married woman died in unnatural conditions just 3 years after her marriage. Her parents informed that she was frequently troubled because of demand of dowry from her inlaws.Her autopsy will be conducted under which section?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Sec. 176 CrPC. Sec. 176 CrPC is correct because it pertains to a situation where there is suspicion of death due to unnatural causes, such as homicide, suicide, or an accident. In this case, the woman’s death is described as unnatural, and there is a report of frequent dowry-related troubles, suggesting the possibility of foul play or violence. Section 176 of the Criminal Procedure Code (CrPC) mandates that the death of a person under suspicious circumstances (including the unnatural death of a married woman within seven years of marriage, potentially due to dowry-related harassment or violence) must be investigated by the police and an autopsy must be conducted. This is done to determine the cause of death and whether any criminal offense, such as dowry death, has occurred. Incorrect Options: A. Sec. 174 CrPC This is incorrect because Section 174 CrPC deals with the case of a death under suspicious circumstances, but without specific indications of foul play or suspicion of a criminal act. It allows for an investigation but does not mandate an in-depth inquiry as is required under Section 176 when there are strong suspicions of a criminal act, such as dowry-related issues leading to the woman's death. C. Sec. 302 IPC This is incorrect because Section 302 IPC deals with murder and the punishment for murder. While it is possible that a murder investigation could eventually be initiated if evidence suggests the death was intentional and caused by someone, Section 302 IPC would not be directly relevant at the stage of conducting an autopsy, unless the police have strong evidence of homicide, which isn't confirmed just by the suspicion of dowry issues. D. Sec. 304B IPC This is incorrect because Section 304B IPC addresses the offense of dowry death, which occurs when a woman is subjected to cruelty by her husband or his relatives related to dowry demands and subsequently dies within seven years of marriage. However, the autopsy itself would not be conducted under this section. Section 304B IPC would come into play after the autopsy results and during the legal investigation if dowry-related harassment and death are confirmed.

questions.text: A witness who after taking oath or making a solemn affirmation, willfully makes a false statement which he knows or believes to be false.He is liable to be prosecuted for perjury under which section and with imprisonment upto which time?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Perjury: A witness who after taking oath or making a solemn affirmation, willfully makes a false statement which he knows or believes to be the false (Sec. 191 IPC and Sec. 344 CrPC) is liable to be prosecuted for perjury under Sec. 193 IPC with imprisonment upto 7 years and fine. Perjury: (willful false evidence) - Whoever, being legally bound by an oath or by an express provision of law to state the truth, or being bound by law to make a declaration upon any subject, makes any statement which is false,and which he either knows or believe to be false,is said to give false evidence(sections 191,192 IPC and 344 CrPC). - Punishment of up to 7 years(section 193 IPC)

questions.text: Dying Declaration is considered as which type of evidence?
questions.solution: Correct Response (D) Hearsay evidence A dying declaration is considered hearsay evidence because it is a statement made by a person who is not available to testify in court, typically because they have passed away. However, under Section 32(1) of the Indian Evidence Act, a dying declaration is treated as an exception to the hearsay rule. It is admissible in court because it is presumed that a person on the verge of death would not lie, as they are aware of the impending consequences of their words. Dying declarations are often crucial in cases of homicide or accidents where the victim provides their account of the incident before their death. Incorrect Responses: (A) Circumstantial evidence Circumstantial evidence refers to evidence that indirectly proves a fact by providing a chain of circumstances that lead to a logical conclusion. A dying declaration does not fall under this category because it directly addresses the cause or circumstances of the declarant's death. Hence, this option is incorrect. (B) Oral evidence Oral evidence refers to statements made by a witness in court under oath during a trial. A dying declaration, although often verbal, is not oral evidence in the strict sense because it is not made under oath or directly in court. Therefore, this option is incorrect. (C) Documentary evidence Documentary evidence involves written or recorded materials, such as contracts, letters, or photographs. While a dying declaration may be documented (e.g., recorded or written by a magistrate or another authorized person), it is primarily considered hearsay evidence and not categorized as documentary evidence. Thus, this option is also incorrect.

questions.text: One of the following statements given below is not an indication for conducting in a magistrate inquest?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Deaths due to police firing. (A) Deaths due to police firing Deaths resulting from police firing are not specifically mandated for a magistrate inquest under standard procedures. Such cases are typically handled through a police inquest (conducted by a police officer under Section 174 of the Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC)) unless there are additional circumstances (e.g., custodial deaths, suspicious cases, or public outcry) that might necessitate a magistrate inquest. Therefore, this option is not an indication for a magistrate inquest. Incorrect Responses: (B) Disappearance or death of a person in police custody or during police interrogation Deaths occurring in police custody or during interrogation are specifically listed as indications for conducting a magistrate inquest under Section 176 of the CrPC. These cases require detailed judicial scrutiny due to the high potential for abuse of authority. Hence, this is a valid indication. (C) Death of a convict in jail The death of a convict in jail, whether natural or otherwise, falls under Section 176 of the CrPC, which mandates a magistrate inquest. This ensures transparency and accountability in cases where the individual was under state supervision. Thus, this is a valid indication. (D) Dowry deaths (suicide/death of a woman within 5 years of marriage) Dowry deaths are a specific category under Section 304B of the Indian Penal Code, and they require a magistrate inquest as per Section 176 of the CrPC. The law ensures detailed investigation due to the social and legal implications of such deaths. This is also a valid indication.

questions.text: Given is a list of offenses listed under the category of bailable offenses. Which one of the following does not fall under this category?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Bailable offences are those in which bail can be granted by the law. The court cannot refuse bail, and the police have no right to keep the person in custody. For example, causing death by rash or negligent act (Sec. 304-A IPC), causing miscarriage (Sec. 312 IPC), voluntarily causing hurt (Sec. 323 IPC) and grievous hurt (Sec. 325 IPC). Non-bailable offences are those in which bail cannot be granted. These are the serious offences and the decision is taken by a Judicial Magistrate only. The police must produce the accused before the judge within 24 h of arrest. At that time, the accused has a right to apply for bail himself or through his lawyer, e.g. cases of murder (Sec. 302 IPC), attempt to murder (Sec. 307 IPC), dowry death (Sec. 304-B IPC), causing miscarriage without woman’s consent (Sec. 313 IPC) or voluntarily causing grievous hurt by dangerous weapons (Sec. 326 IPC).

questions.text: Leading questions are not permitted in which type of examination?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Examination-in-Chief (Direct Examination) It is the examination of a witness by the party who calls him.In criminal cases, the public prosecutor commences this examination.Objectives are to place before the court all the facts that bear on the case, and if the witness is an expert, his interpretation of these facts. No leading questions are allowed except in those cases in which the Judge is satisfied that a witness is hostile. Cross-Examination It is the examination of a witness by the adverse party (defense lawyer). The lawyer tries to weaken the evidence of the witness by showing that his details are inaccurate, conflicting, contradictory and untrustworthy. Leading questions are allowed (Sec. 143 IEA). Re-Examination (Re-Direct Examination) It is the examination of a witness subsequent to the cross-examination by the party who called him.Leading questions are not allowed. Opposing lawyer has the right of re-cross-examination on any new point which has been raised.

questions.text: A witness, who after taking oath, willfully makes a statement which he knows or believes to be false is guilty of offence under section?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 193 IPC Section 193 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) pertains to the offense of giving false evidence or fabricating false evidence. It specifically applies to situations where an individual, having taken an oath to tell the truth, willfully makes a false statement, knowing or believing it to be false. This is the correct answer because the act of knowingly providing false evidence after taking an oath directly falls under the ambit of Section 193 IPC, which addresses punishment for false evidence. The law seeks to uphold the integrity of judicial proceedings by penalizing such offenses. Reasons for Incorrect Options: A. 190 IPC: This section deals with the cognizance of offenses by magistrates. It does not relate to the act of giving false evidence. B. 191 IPC: This section defines the term "giving false evidence." While it lays the foundation by explaining what constitutes false evidence, it does not prescribe punishment. Therefore, it is not the correct section for holding someone guilty. C. 192 IPC: This section deals with "fabricating false evidence," which involves creating false evidence with the intention of misleading judicial or legal proceedings. However, it does not cover the specific act of making a false statement under oath.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man was hit by a car, when brought to hospital the casualty medical officer declared him dead. Autopsy shows fatal head trauma, numerous cutaneous abrasions and contusions, and two fractures of the lower legs. The fractures are centered ~8 and 14 inches above the soles of the right and left feet, respectively. What conclusion is suggested regarding the leg fractures?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The described leg fractures are most consistent with “bumper fractures” and indicate the upright nature of the decedent as he was struck by a vehicle. The differing heights above the soles of the feet are compatible with one leg being raised in the process of walking. A bumper fracture is a fracture of the lateral tibial plateau caused by the bumper of a car coming into contact with the outer side of the knee when a person is standing. Specifically, it is caused by a forced valgus applied to the knee. This causes the lateral part of the distal femur and the lateral tibial plateau to come into contact, compressing the tibial plateau and causing the tibia to fracture. The name of the injury is because it was described as being caused by the impact of a car bumper on the lateral side of the knee while the foot is planted on the ground.

questions.text: A 32 year CRPF officer posted in naxalite area is involved in an explosion caused by an improvised explosive device (IED). He sustains a penetrating chest injury. How should this type of blast injury pattern be classified?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Blast injury patterns can be classified into four groups: primary, secondary, tertiary, and quaternary. Secondary blast injuries occur as a result of shrapnel that impacts the body as a result of detonation. This may include screws, ball bearings, or other metal fragments that are packed into the explosive device. It is designed to be antipersonnel in nature, and wounds may look similar to gunshot wounds. In the depicted scenario case, the wound pattern is due to impact of shrapnel, which qualifies as a secondary blast injury.

questions.text: Which collection tube additive should be used for postmortem blood specimens for toxicological analysis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Since some substances important for forensic pathology case work continue to degrade in the blood after death (e.g., cocaine), it is vital to preserve the blood as quickly as practical for toxicological analysis. In this question, sodium fluoride is the only preservative agent listed and is one of the most commonly used. Of note, sodium fluoride is also a weak anticoagulant. A clot activator with gel tube is a serum separator in which the sample should be allowed to clot for several minutes and then centrifuged to separate serum, which can then be removed and used for serum assays or frozen for future use. Note that depending on environmental conditions, blood may begin to clot in the vessels (in situ) within about an hour of death. In addition, hemolysis is common in postmortem samples, which may hinder analysis of serum in an assay-dependent fashion. Ethylenediamine tetra-acetic acid (EDTA) and sodium heparin are anticoagulants; however, their ability to prevent metabolic degradation of substances within the blood is limited and is not as good as sodium fluoride. EDTA is a preferred additive for eventual DNA extraction.

questions.text: On court orders in a case an exhumation was performed in the presence of executive magistrate. The adult skeletal remains are recovered. A skull defect of the posterior right parietal bone is found. What is the best interpretation of this defect?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) A burr hole surgery involves the intentional creation of a circular opening in the skull, often for medical purposes such as relieving intracranial pressure, draining a hematoma, or accessing the brain for surgery. The characteristic features of a burr hole include smooth edges, a round or oval shape, and an absence of associated trauma patterns like radiating fractures or beveling. In this case, the defect on the posterior right parietal bone of the adult skeleton, described without evidence of associated fracture or trauma, strongly suggests that it is the result of a burr hole surgery rather than trauma-related injuries. Reasons for Incorrect Options: A. Entrance gunshot wound: An entrance gunshot wound typically leaves a small, round defect with internal beveling (cone-like narrowing towards the inside of the skull). This is usually accompanied by radiating fractures and evidence of projectile impact. Since no such features are described in this case, an entrance gunshot wound is unlikely. B. Exit gunshot wound: An exit gunshot wound creates an irregular, larger defect with external beveling (cone-like widening towards the outside of the skull). This type of wound is generally more destructive than an entrance wound and is accompanied by significant surrounding bone damage. The smooth, isolated skull defect described here does not match the typical features of an exit gunshot wound. D. Penetrating ice pick injury: An ice pick injury typically leaves a small, narrow puncture wound with irregular edges. This type of injury often penetrates deeply, but the defect is not circular or smooth, as seen with burr hole surgery. Additionally, it is less likely to involve a single, medically precise defect on the posterior parietal bone.

questions.text: A 10-week-old term gestation infant with no birth complications and a normal prenatal course is found deceased face down in a full-sized bed while bed sharing with two obese parents. During scene reconstruction, the parents convey that they were on the edges of the bed. Autopsy shows anterior and posterior lividity. A respiratory viral panel is positive for rhinovirus, and histology shows a mild chronic bronchiolitis. How should the manner of death be classified?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Since the differential diagnosis includes overlay, unsafe bedding, prone position, and possibly natural disease (cardiac conduction anomalies, for example), and because homicide by smothering cannot be excluded as it may leave no physical marks, the best manner of death classification in this case is undetermined. If there was evidence that the baby had been underneath one of the parents, the manner could be classified as accident. In this case, however, the parents do not endorse overlaying, and no definitive evidence is apparent. If there was adequate evidence of airway obstruction by bedding, that could also be considered accident. Although homicide cannot be excluded, there are no overt signs of injury to this infant; thus, intentional harm cannot be concluded with the available evidence.

questions.text: An intoxicated person is brought to the hospital, on the basis of symptoms the doctor suspects cocaine intoxication. What is the principle substance used to screen for cocaine use ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Cocaine is not directly tested in urine screens because of its short half-life and low yield. Benzoylecgonine is the main metabolite of cocaine used to detect previous use. It has a longer half-life than cocaine, and most of the urine drug screens use benzoylecgonine as the basis of previous cocaine use. Anhydroecgonidine is a specific metabolite of crack cocaine but has little use in screening for the use of cocaine. Signs and symptoms of cocaine intoxication :- Acute cocaine toxicity has three reported phases. Phase I (early stimulation) is as follows: Central nervous system (CNS) findings: Mydriasis, headache, bruxism, nausea, vomiting, vertigo, nonintentional tremor (eg, twitching of small muscles, especially facial and finger), tics, preconvulsive movements, and pseudohallucinations (eg, cocaine bugs) Circulatory findings: Possible increase in blood pressure (BP), slowed or increased pulse rate (possibly with ventricular ectopy), and pallor Respiratory findings: Increase in rate and depth Temperature findings: Elevated body temperature Behavioral findings: Euphoria, elation, garrulous talk, agitation, apprehension, excitation, restlessness, verbalization of impending doom, and emotional lability Phase II (advanced stimulation) is as follows: CNS findings: Malignant encephalopathy, generalized seizures and status epilepticus, decreased responsiveness to all stimuli, greatly increased deep tendon reflexes, and incontinence Circulatory findings: Hypertension; tachycardia; and ventricular dysrhythmias (possible), which then result in weak, rapid, irregular pulse and hypotension; and peripheral cyanosis Respiratory findings: Tachypnea, dyspnea, gasping, and irregular breathing pattern Temperature - Severe hyperthermia (possible) Phase III (depression and premorbid state) is as follows: CNS: Coma, areflexia, pupils fixed and dilated, flaccid paralysis, and loss of vital support functions Circulatory: Circulatory failure and cardiac arrest (ventricular fibrillation [VF] or asystole) Respiratory: Respiratory failure, gross pulmonary edema, cyanosis, agonal respirations, and paralysis of respiration

questions.text: Among the given options what is the receptor associated with 3,4-methylenedioxy-methamphetamine?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The receptor most closely associated with the action of 3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine (MDMA) is the 5-HT2A receptor, which is a subtype of serotonin receptors. MDMA is known to primarily act as a serotonin-releasing agent, significantly increasing serotonin levels in the synaptic cleft. The 5-HT2A receptor plays a key role in mediating the psychoactive and hallucinogenic effects of MDMA by modulating serotonin signaling in the brain. This receptor is critical in influencing mood, perception, and cognition, which are hallmark effects of MDMA use. Reasons for Incorrect Options: B. CB2: The CB2 receptor is part of the endocannabinoid system and is primarily found in the immune system. It does not play a significant role in the effects of MDMA. CB2 is more associated with inflammation and immune response regulation. C. CB1: The CB1 receptor is also part of the endocannabinoid system but is located in the central nervous system. It is primarily associated with the psychoactive effects of cannabinoids, such as THC in cannabis. CB1 is not significantly involved in MDMA’s mechanism of action, which is serotonin-based. D. µ (Mu receptor): The µ-opioid receptor (Mu receptor) is primarily involved in the analgesic and euphoric effects of opioids like morphine and heroin. While MDMA may have some minor indirect effects on the opioid system, it primarily acts through the serotonergic system and has no direct affinity for the µ-opioid receptor.

questions.text: A 20 year old college student is brought to the hospital with seizures the body temperature of the patient is recorded as 110°F . On probing further the patients hostel roommate describes that the patient consumed a substance contained in a small plastic bag. He subsequently becomes delirious then started exhibiting seizures. Considering the history and the circumstances what did the patient likely consume ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Cocaine The clinical presentation of seizures, delirium, and an extremely high body temperature (hyperthermia of 110°F), combined with a history of substance consumption, strongly suggests cocaine intoxication. Cocaine is a powerful central nervous system stimulant that can cause a hyperadrenergic state, leading to symptoms such as: Hyperthermia – Cocaine increases metabolic activity and disrupts thermoregulation, leading to dangerously high body temperatures. Seizures – Cocaine lowers the seizure threshold, making seizures a common complication in acute toxicity. Delirium – The stimulant effects can cause agitation, confusion, and delirium. The use of a small plastic bag to store the substance is also consistent with how cocaine is commonly packaged and consumed. Reasons for Incorrect Options: B. Fentanyl: Fentanyl is a synthetic opioid that typically causes central nervous system depression rather than stimulation. Symptoms of fentanyl intoxication include respiratory depression, pinpoint pupils, and sedation/coma. Hyperthermia and seizures are not typical features of fentanyl overdose. C. Heroin: Heroin, another opioid, causes effects similar to fentanyl, such as central nervous system and respiratory depression. It does not cause seizures or hyperthermia. On the contrary, it often leads to hypothermia in overdose situations. D. Marijuana: Marijuana (cannabis) does not cause seizures, delirium, or hyperthermia. The primary effects of marijuana are sedation, altered perception, and mild euphoria. Its toxicity profile does not match the symptoms described in this case.

questions.text: A 25-year-old sewer worker without wearing protective gear entering a manhole, collapses and dies within moments. First respondents report a strong rotten egg odor. Autopsy shows cyanosis and pulmonary edema. What chemical should be suspected?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Hydrogen sulfide is a highly toxic gas that has a characteristic rotten egg odor. It is commonly found in sewer systems, where it is produced by the anaerobic decomposition of organic material. The clinical presentation in this case, including sudden collapse, cyanosis, and pulmonary edema, is characteristic of hydrogen sulfide poisoning. Hydrogen sulfide acts by inhibiting cytochrome c oxidase in the mitochondrial electron transport chain, similar to cyanide, resulting in cellular hypoxia despite normal oxygen levels in the blood. High concentrations of H2S can cause immediate collapse and death due to respiratory paralysis and cardiac effects. Incorrect Options: A. Ammonia: Ammonia is a strong irritant gas with a pungent smell, often found in industrial or agricultural settings. It primarily causes irritation to the eyes, skin, and respiratory tract but does not cause rapid death or the "rotten egg odor" described in this case. B. Carbon monoxide: Carbon monoxide (CO) is a colorless, odorless gas. CO poisoning causes symptoms like headache, dizziness, confusion, and cherry-red discoloration of the skin due to carboxyhemoglobin formation. The absence of cherry-red skin and the presence of a "rotten egg odor" rule out carbon monoxide. C. Cyanide: Cyanide is a highly toxic chemical that can also inhibit cytochrome c oxidase, leading to cellular hypoxia. However, cyanide is odorless (or has a faint bitter almond smell, detectable only by some people) and is not typically associated with environments like sewers.

questions.text: A 3 year old child who lives in a suburban area is brought to the clinic with complaints of altered mental status. Subsequent hospital workup documents a microcytic, hypochromic anemia. A skeletal survey reveals radiopaque densities at multiple metaphyseal plates. What underlying disease process should be suspected?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The key features in this case—altered mental status, microcytic hypochromic anemia, and radiopaque densities at multiple metaphyseal plates—are strongly suggestive of lead poisoning. Lead toxicity in children can result from exposure to lead-based paints, contaminated water, or dust, especially in older suburban homes. The radiopaque densities seen on the skeletal survey, often referred to as "lead lines," are due to lead deposition in the metaphyseal regions of growing bones. These lines appear as dense bands in the metaphysis and are characteristic of chronic lead exposure. Lead also causes microcytic, hypochromic anemia, as lead interferes with hemoglobin synthesis by inhibiting enzymes such as aminolevulinic acid dehydratase and ferrochelatase. In addition, neurological symptoms, including altered mental status and developmental delays, are common in lead poisoning. Reasons for Incorrect Options: B. Folate deficiency: Folate deficiency typically causes macrocytic anemia, not microcytic. It is associated with neural tube defects in infants or megaloblastic anemia in adults. Folate deficiency does not cause radiopaque metaphyseal lines or the neurological findings seen here. C. Fracture with callus formation: A fracture with callus formation can show radiopaque areas in the bones, but this would typically be localized to the site of the fracture and not involve multiple metaphyseal plates. The systemic features like altered mental status and anemia also point away from a simple fracture. D. Vitamin B12 deficiency: Vitamin B12 deficiency causes macrocytic anemia (not microcytic) and can lead to neurological deficits such as peripheral neuropathy and cognitive disturbances. However, it does not cause the characteristic radiopaque metaphyseal lines seen in lead toxicity.

questions.text: A 34 year old man who previously used to work in a corporate firm was fired from his job due to global recession. He develops suicidal ideation and was visiting a therapist for the same. Today he is found dead in his car. Inside the car, several household cleaners are recovered. Autopsy shows pulmonary edema but no other significant findings. You are the medical officer called to the the scene. What should you instruct the laboratory analyzing the postmortem toxicology samples to analyze specimens for?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The scenario suggests suicide by poisoning, likely through the ingestion or inhalation of toxic substances. The household cleaners found in the car may contain sodium hypochlorite or other chemicals, which can release toxic fumes, potentially including hydrogen sulfide (H?S) or chlorine gas. When hydrogen sulfide is inhaled or absorbed, it can cause severe toxicity, leading to pulmonary edema, hypoxia, and death. Thiosulfate is used as an antidote for hydrogen sulfide poisoning, as it helps to neutralize the toxic effects of sulfide ions. The laboratory should analyze the postmortem samples for thiosulfate, as its presence or absence would help confirm if hydrogen sulfide poisoning was involved. Reasons for Incorrect Options: B. Carbon monoxide: Carbon monoxide poisoning is often associated with exposure to incomplete combustion of fuels (e.g., car exhaust, burning charcoal). Although carbon monoxide can cause pulmonary edema and death, it is less likely to be the cause in this case because the scenario does not suggest exposure to a source of carbon monoxide like a car engine running in a confined space. C. Ethanol: Ethanol is commonly found in cases of alcohol poisoning, but the patient's history of suicidal ideation and the use of household cleaners do not point to ethanol consumption. Additionally, ethanol would likely cause CNS depression, rather than pulmonary edema, and is not a likely cause in this context. D. Methane: Methane is a colorless, odorless gas primarily associated with natural gas and is typically not a direct cause of poisoning. While inhalation in very high concentrations could lead to suffocation due to oxygen displacement, it does not fit the clinical presentation of pulmonary edema and toxic exposure from household cleaners.

questions.text: A 48-year-old chronic alcoholic man has been sent to prison in charges of domestic violence against complaint filed by his wife. He had no significant medical history and was not on medications. On his third day at prison he is brought to the prison’s medical officer with complaints of demonstrating odd behavior and he also described visual hallucinations. He subsequently experienced seizure-like activity and then became unresponsive. What is the likely underlying cause of this patient’s condition ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) DTs is the most severe manifestation of alcohol withdrawal. It occurs 3-10 days following the last drink. Clinical manifestations include altered mental status (global confusion) and sympathetic overdrive (autonomic hyperactivity), which can progress to cardiovascular collapse. Minor alcohol withdrawal is characterized by tremor, anxiety, nausea, vomiting, and insomnia. Major alcohol withdrawal signs and symptoms include visual hallucinations and auditory hallucinations, whole body tremor, vomiting, diaphoresis, and hypertension (high blood pressure) Treatments for delirium tremens:- Supportive therapy: This important component of treatment of alcohol withdrawal syndrome and delirium tremens (DTs) includes providing a calm, quiet, well-lit environment; reassurance; ongoing reassessment; attention to fluid and electrolyte deficits; and treatment of any coexisting addictions. Thiamine: Thiamine can be useful for preventing Wernicke encephalopathy (confusion, ataxia, ophthalmoplegia), an acute disorder caused by thiamine deficiency, and Korsakoff syndrome (memory impairment, amnesia), a late manifestation of thiamine deficiency. Benzodiazepines

questions.text: A 34 year old male weighing approx 62 kg is caught by the traffic police for rash driving and over speeding, a blood sample examination revealed ethanol concentration of 120 mg/dL. Prior to being caught the man was at a cocktail party with his friends where he had his last drink 2 hours ago. Assuming no confounding variables. What is the best approximation of the decedent’s blood ethanol at the time he quit drinking 2 hours ago ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The rate of ethanol metabolism varies among individuals, but a general approximation is that ethanol is eliminated from the bloodstream at a rate of about 0.015 g/dL per hour (or 15 mg/dL per hour). Given that the man has a blood ethanol concentration of 120 mg/dL after 2 hours, the best estimate of his ethanol concentration at the time he stopped drinking would be 120 mg/dL + (2 hours * 15 mg/dL/hour) = 150 mg/dL. This calculation assumes a standard elimination rate of ethanol and no other confounding factors such as liver disease, medications, or other individual variations. Reasons for Incorrect Options: A. 90 mg/dL: This value would be too low, as it suggests the man was drinking less ethanol, but based on the standard metabolic rate, his ethanol concentration would have been much higher at the time he stopped drinking. C. 140 mg/dL: While close, this value doesn't account for the full 2-hour metabolic elimination of ethanol at the standard rate of 15 mg/dL per hour. The concentration would be closer to 150 mg/dL rather than 140 mg/dL. D. 120 mg/dL: This is the concentration measured after 2 hours, not the concentration at the time he stopped drinking. Therefore, this is not the correct answer.

questions.text: A 58 year old man living in a rural area has been brought to the local PHC in altered sensorium, family members report that the man had a fall at home and striked his head on ground. After initial management the patient is referred to the higher centre where CT scan demonstrated a subdural hematoma. Patient remains obtunded during hospitalization and dies 1 week after presentation. Hospital blood drawn around the time of admission has all been disposed. What is the best postmortem source to send for toxicology in this scenario?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) In this case, the patient has suffered a head injury and subsequently developed a subdural hematoma, which eventually led to his death. The best source for postmortem toxicology in this situation is subdural blood. This is because the blood in the subdural space is likely to contain higher concentrations of any substances (such as drugs or toxins) that were present in the system at the time of the injury. Given that the patient had a fall and struck his head, there is a possibility that subdural hemorrhage could affect the absorption, distribution, and clearance of any substances, making subdural blood an ideal source to detect toxins. Additionally, because the blood drawn at the time of admission was disposed of, subdural blood is the next best option for postmortem toxicology. Reasons for Incorrect Options: A. Liver tissue: The liver is an excellent source for detecting toxins and drugs in general, as it is a major site for metabolism and detoxification. However, in this case, the subdural blood is likely to provide more immediate and relevant information regarding the substances present at the time of the injury, especially because of the proximity to the traumatic event. B. Peripheral blood: Peripheral blood can be useful in postmortem toxicology; however, in cases of traumatic injury like a subdural hematoma, peripheral blood might not reflect the concentration of substances as accurately as blood from the area directly affected by the trauma. Subdural blood is more likely to contain traces of toxins or drugs that may have been administered or ingested shortly before or after the fall. D. Vitreous fluid: Vitreous fluid (from the eye) is often used for detecting certain substances, particularly in cases where blood has clotted or is unavailable. However, it is generally more useful in cases of metabolic disturbances or postmortem drug testing after a long period of time. In this scenario, where the cause of death is related to head trauma and the blood sample was disposed of, subdural blood is likely to provide more accurate results for detecting toxins relevant to the timing of the injury.

questions.text: Which of the following is a reliable indicator of a live birth?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Food in the stomach is a reliable indicator of life after birth. However, it is often absent in cases of neonatacide due to the short survival period. Similarly, umbilical cord changes may be helpful in cases with 1+ day survival. The hydrostatic float test assumes a live birth will result in lung inflation due to breathing and thus flotation when portions of lung are placed in formalin (versus sinking of uninflated lungs and compared to flotation of liver from the same decedent to assess for decomposition gases). However, this classic procedure is of limited value in assessing live birth for a variety of reasons. Decomposition may produce gas and induce floating of tissue in a stillborn. Live birth with subsequent drowning and inhalation of water may result in lungs sinking. Lung sections are also well known to sink in cases of diffuse alveolar damage. Meconium may be released in utero during fetal stress.

questions.text: During an autopsy being conducted for an unnatural death, the following finding is observed, your professor asks you to tell the approximate age of this myocardial infarction. Which of the following would be a correct answer ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The given image shows a healed myocardial infarction, anterior left ventricle. There is diffuse scarring (white) with marked thinning of the ventricle (aneurysm). The correct answer is 6 months because about 2 months after a myocardial infarction, white fibrous scar tissue appears and would be expected to be seen at 6 months as well. No grossly visible changes are observed the first 4 hours after an infarct. Mottling can appear as early as 4 hours and up to 24 hours after the infarct. Acute myocardial infarction (MI) indicates irreversible myocardial injury resulting in necrosis of a significant portion of myocardium (generally >1 cm). The term "acute" denotes infarction less than 3-5 days old, when the inflammatory infiltrate is primarily neutrophilic. Acute MI may be either of the nonreperfusion type, in which case the obstruction to blood flow is permanent, or of the reperfusion type, in which the obstruction or lack of blood flow is long enough in duration (generally hours) but is reversed or restored after myocardial cell death occurs.

questions.text: A 50 year old presented to the emergency department with complaint of headache and blurred vision. Patient described headache as “worst headache of my life”. Even after best efforts of the medical team the patient died. An autopsy finding of the patient is given in the image below, identify the source of hemorrhage.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The description of the patient's symptoms, including the "worst headache of my life" and the sudden onset of headache and blurred vision, suggests a diagnosis of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), which is often caused by the rupture of an aneurysm. The anterior communicating artery (AComA) is one of the most common sites for cerebral aneurysms. These aneurysms typically present with a sudden, severe headache (often described as the worst headache of a person's life) and can cause fatal complications, such as brain hemorrhage, neurological deficits, and coma. The subarachnoid hemorrhage typically involves bleeding around the base of the brain, and the AComA is a common site for aneurysms that result in this type of bleeding. Reasons for Incorrect Options: B. Basilar artery: The basilar artery supplies the brainstem and posterior circulation of the brain. While aneurysms of the basilar artery can cause subarachnoid hemorrhage, they are less common compared to anterior circulation aneurysms. Additionally, the symptoms described (headache and blurred vision) are more characteristic of an aneurysm in the anterior circulation, like that of the anterior communicating artery. C. Internal carotid artery: The internal carotid artery is a major vessel supplying blood to the brain, but an aneurysm of this artery would typically cause intracranial hemorrhage in the regions it supplies (such as the anterior cerebral artery or middle cerebral artery). However, it is not the most common site for the type of headache and hemorrhage described in this case, particularly with the “worst headache of my life” symptom. D. Middle cerebral artery: The middle cerebral artery (MCA) is another major cerebral vessel, and its aneurysms can cause subarachnoid hemorrhage as well. However, MCA aneurysms typically result in a different clinical presentation, such as focal neurological deficits or hemiparesis, depending on the area of the brain affected. The anterior communicating artery aneurysm, on the other hand, is more often associated with the classic description of a "worst headache" and is a more common cause of subarachnoid hemorrhage in this context.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman is found disarticulated and burned inside a barrel 2 days after she was last seen. At that time she had been arguing with her boyfriend. Autopsy shows extensively charred human remains, with only portions of major internal organs present. Soot is not definitively identified in the remaining airways. Toxicological analysis of remaining liver tissue demonstrates delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) at 0.05 mg/kg and oxycodone at 0.1 mg/kg. What is the best characterization of the cause of death?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Homicidal violence • Answer A is incorrect. There is no evidence of carbon monoxide exposure (no soot in lungs). Directed analysis for carboxyhemoglobin is recommended; if no blood is present, splenic tissue is suggested. • Answer B is incorrect. The liver drug concentrations are not associated with toxicity. • Answer C is correct. The classification of cause and manner of death elicits many discussions among forensic pathologists. In the authors’ opinion, based on the circumstances surrounding the death, lack of soot in the airways, and nontoxic drug concentrations in the liver, it is best to classify this death as “homicidal violence,” despite “homicide” being a manner of death. • Answer D is incorrect. There is no evidence of life during the fire, as there was no soot in the larger airways of the lungs. Directed analysis for carboxyhemoglobin is recommended; if no blood is present, splenic tissue is suggested. • Answer E is incorrect. In the authors’ opinion, based on the circumstances surrounding the death, lack of soot in the airways, and nontoxic drug concentrations in the liver, it is best to classify this death as “homicidal violence.”

questions.text: On a clear road 30-year-old female is crossing the street and is hit by an automobile. Nearby people call for ambulance, patient dies en route to the hospital. The driver flees the scene and turns himself in the next day. Driver claims that he thought he had killed a deer and did not realize somebody had died until he saw the event being reported in local news. The police files negligent homicide charges against the driver. What is the manner of death?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The women died as a result of the blunt force injuries sustained from trauma caused by the automobile. Since there is no evidence the automobile was used as a weapon, the manner is best classified as accident. Criminal charges can be pursued regardless of the manner of death. Since there is no evidence that the automobile was used as a weapon, the manner should not be classified as homicide. Death from blunt force injuries is not a natural death. Unless there is clear evidence that the decedent deliberately killed herself by throwing herself in front of the automobile, the manner should not be ruled suicide.

questions.text: What drug is most commonly associated with excited delirium?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Excited delirium (EXD), has been referred to by many other names – Bell’s mania, lethal catatonia, acute exhaustive mania and agitated delirium. Excited (or agitated) delirium is characterized by agitation, aggression, acute distress and sudden death, often in the pre-hospital care setting. It is typically associated with the use of drugs that alter dopamine processing, hyperthermia, and, most notably, sometimes with death of the affected person in the custody of law enforcement. Subjects typically die from cardiopulmonary arrest. Methamphetamine, PCP and LSD have been, but by far the most prevalent drug of abuse found on toxicology screening was cocaine.

choices.text: Hyperextension injuries sustained in a jump from a bridge
Motor vehicle crash injuries of an ejected passenger
Motor vehicle crash injuries of a restrained driver

questions.text: What is the best characterization of the external injuries in this man shown in Figure 3.1 below?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Pictured is a male torso with numerous roughly parallel, some what linear abrasions. This pattern is characteristic of “road rash,” which occurs when a body surface is dragged or otherwise propelled across an abrasive surface. Of the choices, the most reasonable scenario would be that in which the individual was ejected from a vehicle and then traversed the road for some distance. The linear aspect chest and then to the right abdomen. Abrasion or contusion may also be present in of the abrasions is due to the directional inertia, while the extent of the abrasions provides some information regarding the surface area in contact with the abrasive surface (commonly a road). Hyperextension injury is characterized by stretching, and frequently laceration of the skin from a force from the opposite side of the injury. For example, hyperextension injury from an auto–pedestrian collision in which the pedestrian is struck from behind would likely be apparent on the anterior body surfaces in areas most prone to hyperextension such as the inguinal regions. Such injuries are frequently bilateral if the impact was straight on. A restrained driver in a motor vehicle collision might show abrasions that approximate the location of the seatbelt—across the left shoulder and association with the lap-belt portion of the modern seatbelt. Injuries due to moving water may have a similar appearance if the body of water is shallow and the body is coming into contact with the abrasive surface of the river bed. However, the body would likely change orientation to the abrasive surface as it traversed the moving water, so the injury pattern would be expected to be less regular.

questions.text: A 30 year old man was involved in a motor vehicle accident on the national highway near delhi, the emergency team brought the patient to hospital with the injury depicted below to the right side of the face. What was the most likely position of this individual during the crash?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The depicted injuries consist of punctate, linear, and angulated cuts, likely due to shattering of the tempered glass side window in the vehicle (“dicing” injury). The location of this injury on the body, especially in seat-belted riders, suggests their sitting location in the vehicle. In this instance, with the injury located on the right side of the face, the decedent was likely the driver of the vehicle. (This is as it applies to standard vehicles in India where traditionally the driver’s side is on the right.) A cyclist struck by a car would likely have road rash/brush burn abrasions, but not the typical aggregate of cuts and punctures associated with dicing injury from shattered tempered side window glass.

questions.text: What is the depicted forehead injury in ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) A laceration is a tear or cut in the skin caused by blunt force trauma, which often results in a jagged or irregular wound. It typically occurs when an object impacts the skin with force, causing it to tear. The nature of the injury depicted in this case, if it is a jagged, irregular wound, fits the description of a laceration. Lacerations can occur from various accidents or trauma, including falling, hitting objects, or blunt force impacts to the forehead. Reasons for Incorrect Options: A. Animal bite: An animal bite would typically result in puncture wounds or small, round wounds, often with associated signs of infection or contamination from bacteria present in the animal's mouth. Animal bite injuries are usually not jagged and irregular like a laceration. B. Electrical injury: Electrical injuries usually cause burns or entry/exit wounds at the point of contact with electrical current. These wounds can appear as burn marks, sometimes with entry and exit points on the skin. However, they do not typically present as jagged, torn wounds seen in lacerations. C. Incised wound: An incised wound is a clean, sharp cut caused by a sharp-edged object like a knife. These wounds are usually well-defined, with smooth edges, unlike a laceration, which tends to have irregular, jagged edges. The description provided fits more with a laceration than an incised wound.

questions.text: In the image given below, identify the likely cause of death ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hanging is suggested by the protrusion of the tongue with postmortem drying artifact in the photograph. Full suspension of the body results in lifting of the neck organs with consequent tongue protrusion. Manual or ligature strangulation does not normally lift the neck organs upward causing pronounced protrusion of the tongue. Also, additional injury to the skin and soft tissues of the neck is expected. A layer-by-layer neck dissection primarily to exclude hemorrhage is a useful tool in this respect. Smothering is the blocking of the external airways (nose and mouth). Smothering may leave only subtle signs such as damage to the oral mucosa or may leave no signs at all. It does not cause lifting of the neck organs upward with protrusion of the tongue.

questions.text: Image of head of a 30 year old man is given below. What is the best description of the pictured wound ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) In the case of a contact gunshot wound, the muzzle of the firearm is in direct contact with the skin at the time of the shot. This results in specific characteristics that can be observed in the wound, including: Burning or charring of the skin around the entrance site. Soot or gunpowder burns around the wound. Tissue damage from the force and heat of the gunshot. The wound is typically more round or irregular due to the gun’s muzzle being pressed against the skin. Given the context of the wound, it fits the description of a contact gunshot wound where the firearm was pressed against the skin when fired, causing these distinctive features. Reasons for Incorrect Options: A. Close-range gunshot wound: A close-range gunshot wound refers to a gunshot fired at a short distance but not in direct contact with the skin. While gunpowder residue may still be present, there won’t be the same extent of tissue damage or charring that is typically seen in a contact wound. C. Exit gunshot wound: An exit gunshot wound is the point where the bullet exits the body, which typically appears larger and more irregular than an entrance wound. Exit wounds are usually not associated with the burning or soot characteristics seen in contact or close-range wounds. D. Indeterminate range gunshot wound: An indeterminate range gunshot wound occurs when the distance between the shooter and the target is unclear. It could display gunpowder residue, but would lack the charred tissue or specific damage found in contact wounds. Without further distinguishing features, it is less likely to be the best description for this wound.

questions.text: The number of equally sized lead balls in one pound is defined as?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) For firearms, shotguns in particular, gauge is defined as the number of lead balls to make up one pound. For example, 24 gauge means that 24 equal round lead balls are in a pound and that each ball is 1/12 of a pound. Birdshot is a designation for small lead pellets used in hunting small game such as birds. The size of birdshot increases as the labeling number decreases. Bore is the term used to identify the internal diameter of the barrel of a firearm usually expressed in inches or millimeters. Buckshot is a designation for lead pellets that are larger than birdshot and used to hunt larger game such as deer or bear. Caliber is used to designate the diameter of the barrel, expressed in inches or millimeters through which the largest bullet (projectile) can safely pass.

questions.text: In a person who initially survive an explosion what is the most common cause of death ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The most common cause of death for people who initially survive an explosion is pulmonary barotrauma, also known as blast lung, which can manifest as contusion, intraparenchymal hemorrhage, edema, or any combination of these. Classification of Blast Injuries (a) Primary Blast Injuries (PBI): Injuries caused by the over-pressure blast wave. Almost always affects air-filled structures and structures with air-fluid interface like lung, gastrointestinal tract, tympanic membrane, blood vessels. These are more manifest with high energy explosives. Pulmonary PBI is the cause of mortality in most and includes lung contusion, alveolar rupture, air embolism and ARDS like picture. Air embolism involves cerebral or spinal vessels and produces neurological features indistinguishable from direct injuries. Cardiovascular changes of PBI include a fall in stroke volume, bradycardia and hypotension. PBI of the gastrointestinal tract is almost always seen with lung and ear injuries. Intestinal PBI is more commonly seen in underwater injuries and generally involves the fixed parts of the colon with perforation. (b) Secondary Blast Injuries: Injuries caused by flying shrapnel and present as penetrating organ injury. These are common to any type of explosions and account for the largest class of injuries. (c) Tertiary Blast Injuries: These are injuries caused due to the blast wind movement moving bodies and debris. Paediatric injuries are more severe due to their smaller body weight and structure [6]. (d) Quaternary Injuries refer to the burns, injuries caused due to toxic fumes, crush injuries, exacerbation of chronic diseases like asthma and psychiatric disorders. These injuries may add to the delayed fatalities. (e) Quinary Blast Injuries are a more recent addition and occurs commonly after attack with incendiary devices and is characterized by a constant hyper-inflammatory state syndrome. This hyper-inflammatory state cannot be explained by injuries that are seen after other blast injuries. Present hypothesis is that this state is due to the toxic substances in the blast explosive being inhaled or absorbed through skin. Penta-erythritol-tetra-nitrate (PETN) has been implicated as one such toxin.

questions.text: A 28 year old soldier is involved in an explosion caused by an improvised explosive device (IED). He sustained multiple injuries including compound fracture of the shaft of tibia as a result of hitting a vehicle after being propelled by the shock wave of the blast. How should this type of blast injury pattern be classified?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) In the context of a blast injury, the injuries are classified based on the mechanism by which they occur. The tertiary blast injury occurs when the individual is propelled by the shock wave of the explosion and strikes a solid object, such as a vehicle, leading to blunt force trauma or impact injuries. In this case, the soldier was propelled by the shock wave of the improvised explosive device (IED) and hit a vehicle, resulting in a compound fracture of the shaft of the tibia. This is a classic example of a tertiary blast injury, where the person’s body is thrown by the blast and strikes a secondary object, causing injury. Reasons for Incorrect Options: A. Primary: Primary blast injuries are caused by the direct effect of the blast wave on the body, particularly on gas-filled organs like the lungs, ears, and gastrointestinal tract. These injuries are typically internal and involve damage to the organs due to the high-pressure shock wave. The soldier in this case did not sustain primary blast injuries (such as lung contusion or tympanic membrane rupture). B. Secondary: Secondary blast injuries occur when debris or shrapnel from the explosion strikes the person, causing penetrating trauma. This type of injury would involve cuts, punctures, or lacerations from flying objects, but the soldier's injury was due to blunt force trauma from hitting a vehicle, not from shrapnel. D. Quaternary: Quaternary blast injuries encompass a wide range of injuries that are not directly caused by the blast itself but result from other factors related to the explosion, such as burns, toxic inhalation, or crush injuries from buildings collapsing. While the soldier may have experienced other injuries, the specific injury described (fracture from hitting a vehicle) is classified as tertiary.

questions.text: A 40 year old man is found deceased on a street after an assault with multiple sharp force injuries to his chest. The injury below is found on the back. What weapon was likely used?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The description suggests that the victim sustained multiple sharp force injuries to the chest, and the injury pattern on the back implies the use of a serrated weapon. A serrated knife leaves a characteristic saw-tooth pattern in the tissue, which is evident in the wound. The uneven, jagged edges of the wound would align with the type of injury caused by a serrated blade, which is designed to cut through tissue with a "sawing" motion. Reasons for Incorrect Options: A. Broken glass bottle: A broken glass bottle is typically a blunt object, and although it can cause lacerations, it generally does not leave the specific type of sharp, jagged wound associated with serrated edges. The injury from a broken bottle is more likely to be irregular and not characteristic of the pattern described. B. Scissors: Scissors can produce sharp force injuries, but they typically result in a more clean and straight-edged cut, rather than a serrated pattern. Additionally, scissors would be less likely to produce multiple sharp force injuries compared to a knife. D. Single-edged knife: A single-edged knife would cause a cleaner, more uniform cut and would not leave the distinct serrated pattern seen in the wound described. A serrated knife is more likely to leave an irregular, jagged wound due to its design.

questions.text: A 45 year old man is found dead near his house, the autopsy demonstrates hemorrhage from the right ear canal. No fractures and no intracranial hemorrhages are present, and no other findings are identified. What cause of death do you suspect?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The effect of a lighting strike on a body is analogous to a blast injury. A common finding is rupture of the tympanic membrane that may be associated with hemorrhage from the external ear. Other common findings include singeing of hair. It is believed that the massive voltage direct current discharge accompanying a lightning strike is not universally fatal due to the extremely short duration of the incident as well as the fact that those “struck by lightning” may actually experience secondary lightning impacts or arcing injury. Examination of the clothing including the shoes may also be informative as it may demonstrate extensive tearing and possibly burning beyond that expected for the condition of the remains.

questions.text: A 30 year old man is trapped in fire at a warehouse, fire fighters recover the man deceased, with extensive thermal changes including widespread charring. Which of the following cannot be assessed during autopsy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Rigor mortis, cannot be assessed when significant thermal injury is present due to the heat contraction of the skeletal muscles, often “fixing” limbs in place. Rigor mortis (Latin: rigor "stiffness", and mortis "of death"), or postmortem rigidity, is the third stage of death. It is one of the recognizable signs of death, characterized by stiffening of the limbs of the corpse caused by chemical changes in the muscles postmortem (mainly calcium). After death, aerobic respiration in an organism ceases, depleting the source of oxygen used in the making of adenosine triphosphate (ATP). ATP is required to cause separation of the actin-myosin cross-bridges during relaxation of muscle. When oxygen is no longer present, the body may continue to produce ATP via anaerobic glycolysis. When the body's glycogen is depleted, the ATP concentration diminishes, and the body enters rigor mortis because it is unable to break those bridges.

questions.text: Regarding the given image, what is the best characterization of the findings featured on the hand ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The findings on the hand are best characterized as a postmortem environmental artifact. This typically refers to changes or marks that occur on the body after death due to the surrounding environment. These can include discolorations, patterns, or impressions caused by exposure to environmental factors such as weather conditions, surfaces the body comes in contact with, or other external environmental influences after death. This type of artifact is not a direct result of trauma or injury but rather an environmental effect that happens postmortem. Reasons for Incorrect Options: A. Immersion change: Immersion changes are alterations to the body caused by immersion in water, leading to features such as washerwoman's skin (wrinkling of the skin) or changes to the body's appearance due to prolonged exposure to water. The findings described here do not fit this pattern, as the injury is not related to water exposure. B. Postmortem animal artifact: A postmortem animal artifact would occur when animals, such as scavengers or insects, interact with the body postmortem. These can include bites, gnaw marks, or other signs of animal activity. However, the findings here are more likely to be related to environmental factors rather than animal activity. D. Spray paint debris: Spray paint debris would typically leave a fine mist of paint particles on the skin, which is not the type of artifact described here. The findings would have a different appearance, such as a fine mist or streaking pattern that would not match environmental effects.
